texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I decided to change some of my infrastructure back to KVM again, and the overall experience has been quite good in Fedora 22. Using libvirt with KVM is a breeze and the virt-manager tools make it even easier. However, I ran into some problems while trying to migrate virtual machines from one server to another.
texts.text: I decided to change some of my infrastructure back to KVM again, and the overall experience has been quite good in Fedora 22. Using libvirt with KVM is a breeze and the virt-manager tools make it even easier. However, I ran into some problems while trying to migrate virtual machines from one server to another.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: The error
texts.text: The error

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# virsh migrate --live --copy-storage-all bastion qemu+ssh://root@192.168.250.33/system
error: internal error: unable to execute QEMU command 'drive-mirror': Failed to connect socket: Connection timed out
texts.text:
# virsh migrate --live --copy-storage-all bastion qemu+ssh://root@192.168.250.33/system
error: internal error: unable to execute QEMU command 'drive-mirror': Failed to connect socket: Connection timed out

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: That error message wasn't terribly helpful. I started running through my usual list of checks:
texts.text: That error message wasn't terribly helpful. I started running through my usual list of checks:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Can the hypervisors talk to each other?'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Can the hypervisors talk to each other?'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Are ssh keys configured?'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Are ssh keys configured?'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='What about ssh host keys being accepted on each side?'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='What about ssh host keys being accepted on each side?'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='SELinux?'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='SELinux?'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Libvirt logs?'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Libvirt logs?'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children="Filesystem permissions for libvirt's directories?">]
texts.text: [<RawText children="Filesystem permissions for libvirt's directories?">]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Libvirt daemon running on both sides?'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Libvirt daemon running on both sides?'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I was pretty confused at this point. A quick Google search didn't reveal too many relevant issues, but I did find a  Red Hat Bug from 2013  that affected RHEL 7. The issue in the bug was that libvirt wasn't using the right ports to talk between servers and those packets were being dropped by iptables. My iptables rules were empty.
texts.text: I was pretty confused at this point. A quick Google search didn't reveal too many relevant issues, but I did find a  Red Hat Bug from 2013  that affected RHEL 7. The issue in the bug was that libvirt wasn't using the right ports to talk between servers and those packets were being dropped by iptables. My iptables rules were empty.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Debug time
texts.text: Debug time

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I ran the same command with
texts.text: I ran the same command with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: LIBVIRT_DEBUG=1
texts.text: LIBVIRT_DEBUG=1

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: at the front:
texts.text: at the front:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: debug.log
texts.text: debug.log

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After scouring the pages and pages of output, I couldn't find anything useful.
texts.text: After scouring the pages and pages of output, I couldn't find anything useful.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Eureka!
texts.text: Eureka!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I spotted an error message briefly in virt-manager or the debug logs that jogged my brain to think about a potential problem: hostnames. Both hosts had a fairly bare
texts.text: I spotted an error message briefly in virt-manager or the debug logs that jogged my brain to think about a potential problem: hostnames. Both hosts had a fairly bare

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /etc/hosts
texts.text: /etc/hosts

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: file without IP/hostname pairs for each hypervisor. After editing both servers'
texts.text: file without IP/hostname pairs for each hypervisor. After editing both servers'

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /etc/hosts
texts.text: /etc/hosts

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: file to include the short and full hostnames for each hypervisor, I tested the live migration one more time.
texts.text: file to include the short and full hostnames for each hypervisor, I tested the live migration one more time.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Success!
texts.text: Success!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The migration went off without a hitch in virt-manager and via the
texts.text: The migration went off without a hitch in virt-manager and via the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: virsh
texts.text: virsh

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: client. I migrated several VM's, including the one running this site, with no noticeable interruption.
texts.text: client. I migrated several VM's, including the one running this site, with no noticeable interruption.
